options.text: The partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (pCO<sub>2</sub>) is higher in the air inside the lungs as compared to venous blood.
The partial pressure of O<sub>2</sub> (pO<sub>2</sub>) is higher in the air inside the lungs as compared to venous blood.
The partial pressure of O<sub>2</sub> (pO<sub>2</sub>) is lower inside the venous blood than in the air in the lung.
The partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (pCO<sub>2</sub>) is higher inside the venous blood than in the air.

solution.text: The partial pressure of O<sub>2 </sub>in the atmospheric air is 158 mm of Hg and that of CO<sub>2</sub> is 0.3 mm of Hg. The partial pressure of oxygen pO<sub>2</sub> in alveolar air is 100 mm Hg and it is only 40 mm Hg in the arterial capillaries of the lungs. Therefore, oxygen from the alveolar air rapidly diffuses due to its higher pO<sub>2</sub> into the blood capillaries. Hence, the partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> (pCO<sub>2</sub>) is lower in the air inside the lungs.
